00020 
00021 /**
00022  * @defgroup accessors Network Interface Accessors
00023  *
00024  * This section is composed of accessors (getters and setters) for various
00025  * network interface configurations. Each accessor requires a socket (see
00026  * wapi_make_socket()) to issue kernel commands. Since each accessor is a
00027  * user-friendly wrapper over various ioctl() calls, unless stated otherwise,
00028  * return values of the accessors are generally obtained by related ioctl()
00029  * calls. In other words, on success, zero is returned.
00030  *
00031  * Pay attention that, all setters require root privileges.
00032  */
00033 
00034 
00035 /**
00036  * @defgroup ifaccessors Generic Network Interface Accessors
00037  * @ingroup accessors
00038  *
00039  * This section consists of generic network interface accessors (IP address,
00040  * gateway, netmask) without any device specific features.
00041  */
00042

00302 
00303 /** Supported operation modes. */
00304 typedef enum {
00305     WAPI_MODE_AUTO      = IW_MODE_AUTO,     /**< Driver decides. */
00306     WAPI_MODE_ADHOC     = IW_MODE_ADHOC,    /**< Single cell network. */
00307     WAPI_MODE_MANAGED   = IW_MODE_INFRA,    /**< Multi cell network, roaming, ... */
00308     WAPI_MODE_MASTER    = IW_MODE_MASTER,   /**< Synchronisation master or access point. */
00309     WAPI_MODE_REPEAT    = IW_MODE_REPEAT,   /**< Wireless repeater, forwarder. */
00310     WAPI_MODE_SECOND    = IW_MODE_SECOND,   /**< Secondary master/repeater, backup. */
00311     WAPI_MODE_MONITOR   = IW_MODE_MONITOR   /**< Passive monitor, listen only. */
00312 } wapi_mode_t;
00313 
00314 
00315 /** Supported operation mode names. */
00316 extern const char *wapi_modes[];

00529 
00530 /**
00531  * @defgroup scan Scanning
00532  *
00533  * This group consists of functions for scanning accessible access points (APs)
00534  * in the range.
00535  *
00536  * Unfortunately provided scanning API by wireless-tools libraries (libiw) is
00537  * quite limited, and doesn't list all APs in the range. (See iw_process_scan()
00538  * of libiw. For iwlist case, it has its own hardcoded magic for this stuff and
00539  * it is not provided by libiw.) For this purpose, we needed to implement our
00540  * own scanning routines. Furthermore, scanning requires extracting binary
00541  * results returned from kernel over a @c char buffer, hence it causes dozens of
00542  * hairy binary compatibility issues. Luckily, libiw provide an API method to
00543  * cope with this: iw_extract_event_stream(). That's the only place in this
00544  * project relying on libiw.
00545  *
00546  * The scanning operation disable normal network traffic, and therefore you
00547  * should not abuse of scan. The scan need to check the presence of network on
00548  * other frequencies. While you are checking those other frequencies, you can
00549  * not be on your normal frequency to listen to normal traffic in the cell. You
00550  * need typically in the order of one second to actively probe all 802.11b
00551  * channels (do the maths). Some cards may do that in background, to reply to
00552  * scan commands faster, but they still have to do it. Leaving the cell for such
00553  * an extended period of time is pretty bad. Any kind of streaming/low latency
00554  * traffic will be impacted, and the user will perceive it (easily checked with
00555  * telnet). People trying to send traffic to you will retry packets and waste
00556  * bandwidth. Some applications may be sensitive to those packet losses in weird
00557  * ways, and tracing those weird behavior back to scanning may take time. If you
00558  * are in ad-hoc mode, if two nodes scan approx at the same time, they won't see
00559  * each other, which may create associations issues. For those reasons, the
00560  * scanning activity should be limited to what's really needed, and continuous
00561  * scanning is a bad idea. --- Jean Tourrilhes
00562  *
00563  * @{
00564  */
00565 
00566 
00567 /**
00568  * Starts a scan on the given interface. Root privileges are required to start a
00569  * scan.
00570  */
00571 int wapi_scan_init(int sock, const char *ifname);
00572 
00573 
00574 /**
00575  * Checks the status of the scan process.
00576  *
00577  * @return zero, if data is ready; 1, if data is not ready; negative on failure.
00578  */
00579 int wapi_scan_stat(int sock, const char *ifname);
00580 
00581 
00582 /**
00583  * Collects the results of a scan process.
00584  *
00585  * @param[out] aps Pushes collected @c wapi_scan_info_t into this list.
00586  */
00587 int wapi_scan_coll(int sock, const char *ifname, wapi_list_t *aps);
00588 
00589 
00590 /** @} scan */

00594  * @defgroup commons Common Data Structures & Definitions

00598 
00599 /** Path to @c /proc/net/wireless. (Requires procfs mounted.) */
00600 #define WAPI_PROC_NET_WIRELESS "/proc/net/wireless"
00601 
00602 /** Path to @c /proc/net/route. (Requires procfs mounted.) */
00603 #define WAPI_PROC_NET_ROUTE "/proc/net/route"
00604 
00605 /** Buffer size while reading lines from PROC_NET_ files. */
00606 #define WAPI_PROC_LINE_SIZE 1024
00607 
00608 
00609 /** Linked list container for strings. */
00610 typedef struct wapi_string_t {
00611     struct wapi_string_t *next;
00612     char *data;
00613 } wapi_string_t;
00614 
00615 
00616 /** Linked list container for scan results. */
00617 typedef struct wapi_scan_info_t {
00618     struct wapi_scan_info_t *next;
00619     struct ether_addr ap;
00620     int has_essid;
00621     char essid[WAPI_ESSID_MAX_SIZE+1];
00622     wapi_essid_flag_t essid_flag;
00623     int has_freq;
00624     double freq;
00625     int has_mode;
00626     wapi_mode_t mode;
00627     int has_bitrate;
00628     int bitrate;
00629 } wapi_scan_info_t;
00630 
00631 
00632 /** Linked list container for routing table rows. */
00633 typedef struct wapi_route_info_t {
00634     struct wapi_route_info_t *next;
00635     char *ifname;
00636     struct in_addr dest;
00637     struct in_addr gw;
00638     unsigned int flags; /**< See @c RTF_* in @c net/route.h for available values. */
00639     unsigned int refcnt;
00640     unsigned int use;
00641     unsigned int metric;
00642     struct in_addr netmask;
00643     unsigned int mtu;
00644     unsigned int window;
00645     unsigned int irtt;
00646 } wapi_route_info_t;
00647 
00648 
00649 /**
00650  * A generic linked list container. For functions taking @c wapi_list_t type of
00651  * argument, caller is resposible for releasing allocated memory.
00652  */
00653 struct wapi_list_t {
00654     union wapi_list_head_t {
00655         wapi_string_t *string;
00656         wapi_scan_info_t *scan;
00657         wapi_route_info_t *route;
00658     } head;
00659 };
